Montgomery S. et al.Psychosocial Stress, Glucocorticoid Signaling, and Prostate Cancer Health Disparities in African American Men.Cancer Health Disparities. 2020; https://doi.org/10.9777/chd.2020.1005Crossref Google Scholar). It is for these reasons that a multifaceted approach is not only ideal, but necessary, to comprehensively address this disease. There are various funding opportunities available to researchers who have carved out a specific niche dedicated to addressing health disparities. Researchers are aware that if they can incorporate a health-disparities “angle” to their topic of interest, they can seek additional funding beyond what is accessible to the general scientific community. In a time of funding scarcity, it is tempting to get creative and pursue grant money from multiple sources. After all, there is beauty in our ability as scientists to pivot and turn our research focus as scientific questions are ever evolving. However, a real danger exists when researchers grasp for unfamiliar straws out of funding desperation—and those unfamiliar straws happen to involve studies “inclusive” of underrepresented or disease-burdened populations. Culturally sensitive and culturally competent health disparities research requires a deep familiarity with the population of interest. To approach a scientific topic without an intimate knowledge of key variables is an error of experimental design. This statement is not to imply that researchers cannot pursue a health disparities topic outside of their respective ethnicities, but rather that an effort must be made to foster pertinent discussions or include key collaborators whose ethnicities match the population of interest in order to fully understand the cultural nuances that affect the multifaceted contributing factors of disease etiology and health-care experiences. Within the world of health disparities research, these efforts are often lacking or insincere. Because health disparities are not prioritized in the scientific mainstream, a deficiency in adequate resources and materials has been normalized. Although the National Institutes of Health currently call for cell line authentication (National Institutes of Health, 2015aNational Institutes of HealthEnhanced Reproducibility through Rigor and Transparency (effective Jan. 25, 2016). Creative approaches to community-based and translational research are instinctive to researchers whose individual identities align with a culture of interest. For these reasons, adequate representation is imperative to comprehensively address varying degrees of health disparities from the student to faculty level (Figure 1). There should be a logical incentive to recruit STEM talent from surrounding communities of color. But grassroot efforts don’t match intentions even when health disparities research is touted as an institutional priority. While serving on admissions committees, my colleagues and I have been repeatedly disturbed by the absence of targeted recruitment efforts toward underrepresented minorities living in close proximity to campus. Specifically, there is an awkward disregard of talented and capable Black or Latino students in the institutions’ “own backyards”—especially if those backyards are economically disadvantaged. As an alternative approach, I have consistently observed recruitment efforts prioritized toward international students to meet institutional diversity quotas. These international individuals could excel academically but are naturally unfamiliar with pertinent local disparities. The downstream effects of this trend are dangerous. It is not enough to recruit local talent; their ideas and input must be valued. An inherent risk of research insensitivity or misconduct exists at a greater level when the opinions of those familiar with the community’s values are disregarded. In my frequent collaborations with public-health, scientific, and clinical colleagues in a concerted effort to provide prostate cancer education and screening to Black men in underserved communities, there have been several instances when golden nuggets of cultural feedback have been ignored by non-Black individuals unfamiliar with pertinent community context. Strategic advice that would increase the comfort of Black study participants and better answer the scientific questions has been swiftly ignored. It has been in these decisive moments that I have become acutely aware that not all researchers “dedicated” to the cause of health disparities are true allies. Intrinsic racism creeps its way into the decision-making conference rooms. Financial incentives are driving increased representation of researchers who can weigh in on culturally sensitive conversations regarding study design, but true inclusion in these conversations remains elusive. There are a few funding opportunities available to increase underrepresented minority representation at multiple levels of academic career development including institutional training grants and diversity supplements. At the surface, these funding opportunities offer a win-win approach for the institution, the principal investigator, and the trainee. However, based on interactions with my colleagues, there is an underlying sense that the financial incentive to fund an underrepresented minority trainee supersedes and often eclipses the rich cultural perspective and expertise that is brought to the table by the trainee. Many trainees feel a constant pressure by others to prove that they are worthy of their position while simultaneously suppressing individual cultural traits that stick out in the scientific setting. It is ironic that the cultural identity that was a non-negotiable piece of a funding award requirement must later be downplayed for the duration of the award so as not to offend anyone within the work environment. At the same time, our unique cultural traits are also fetishized and highly sought after as we are pulled in many directions as the “token” underrepresented minority frequently advertised to improve institutional aesthetic. For Black researchers whose genuine goal is to eradicate health disparities, we can rise above the aforementioned obstacles when given the opportunity. Despite the challenges, we remain steadfast in our ability to earn academic positions of prestige. Because of the resilience passed on to us by our enslaved ancestors, we have mastered the art of turning lemons into lemonade. We can—and will—flip the script as many ways as necessary to better the health outcomes for ourselves, our families, and our communities. We remain confident in our unique abilities to speak for our culture and represent our best interests. L.W.B. is supported by NIH grant number 1T32CA186895 .

Background This study evaluated the impact of a safe injection safety training on healthcare worker (HCW) practice and knowledge following an HIV outbreak in Roka commune, Cambodia. Methods Surveys were conducted at baseline (September 2016) and seven months after a training intervention (March 2018) using the World Health Organization standardized injection practices assessment tool. HCWs were sampled at 15 purposively government health facilities in two provinces. HCWs were observed during injection practices and interviewed by trained experts from Becton-Dickinson and the Ministry of Health Cambodia. The Rao-Scott chi square test was used test for differences between baseline and follow-up. Results We completed 115 observations of practice at baseline and 206 at post-training follow-up. The proportion of patients whose identification was confirmed by HCWs prior to procedure being performed increased from 40.4% to 98% (p <0.0001). The proportion of HCWs who practiced correct hand hygiene increased from 22.0% to 80.6% (p = 0.056) [therapeutic observations] and 17.2% to 63.4% (p = 0.0012) [diagnostic observations]. Immediate disposal of sharps by HCWs decreased from 96.5% to 92.5% (p = 0.0030). Conclusions We found significant improvements in the practice of patient identity confirmation and hand hygiene but not in the immediate disposal of sharps in the post-training intervention. However, findings are not representative of all HCWs in the country. Further pre-service and in-service training and monitoring are necessary to ensure sustained behavior change.
